Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 2: The advent of an extraordinary lineage
In those days, a splendid city named Kapilavastu (Ser skya gzhi) rose on the banks of the river called Ganga—also known as Bhagirathi (Skal ldan shing rta) or the ‘Waterway for Fortunate Beings.'
Scene working notes: The Vinaya source provides a much more detailed account of the founding of Kapilavastu, which is reproduced in English in Rockhill, pp. 11-12.

Sun of Faith - English: King Simhahanu (Seng ge 'gram), descendant of a line of universal monarchs and member of the Shakya clan, reigned over Kapilavastu.
Simhahanu had eight children, four sons named, respectively, Shuddhodana (Zas gtsang), Shuklodana (Zas dkar), Dronodana (Bre bo zas) and Amrtodana (Bdud rtsi zas);
On the other hand, the Shakya king Suprabuddha (Legs par rab sad) reigned over the Shakya town Devadaha (Lhas bstan)
The people of Kapilavastu and Devadaha lived happily, virtuously and prosperously under the just rule of these two sovereigns.
Simhahanu dreamed of having a universal monarch among his descendants;
whereas Suprabuddha hoped to form an alliance with Simhahanu.

The former had a daughter, a child so remarkable that on seeing her, people would exclaim: “It's hard to believe that the king's daughter belongs to the human race. If all the finest virtues were magically to converge in a single being, then that being would be something like our little princess!”
So it was that the little girl was given the name Maya (Sgyu 'phrul ma, ‘Magical Illusion’), and the oracle priests prophesied that her son would one day become a powerful universal monarch.
King Suprabuddha's wife then gave birth to another baby girl, one even more extraordinary,
who received the name Mahamaya-devi (Lha mo sgyu 'phrul chen mo, ‘Goddess Great Magical Illusion’).

In this case, the oracle priests announced that Mahamaya-devi would one day give birth to a child bearing the thirty-two marks of a great being, a prince destined to reach the rank of a universal monarch.
A few years later, Suprabuddha wrote King Simhahanu the following in a letter:
“I have two remarkable daughters. You may take whichever you please as wife for Shuddhodana.”
“It might be best,” Simhahanu replied, “that he take both princesses.
The younger is already welcome in my house. As for the elder girl, I will have to consult my people.”
He then had Princess Mahamaya-devi, along with her five hundred ladies-in-waiting, received into his kingdom, and all became Prince Shuddhodana's spouses.
Not many months had passed before Simhahanu had to send his eldest son off to subjugate the Pandavas (Skya seng), an enemy tribe that had seized control of the upper hills.
Should his son succeed, the Shakyas promised the king some great recompense.
The prince defeated the Pandavas and as soon as he returned to Kapilavastu, the people asked Simhahanu to make a wish, [so that they could grant it].
“We the Shakyas have a law,” the king stated, “which forbids us to take a second wife from the same family as that of the first wife.
However, a truly wonderful princess has been offered as spouse for the prince but unfortunately it so happens that she is the sister of the first queen.”
The Shakya Council made the desired exception to the rule and Princess Maya and her entourage of five hundred entered the palace of the prince with due magnificence and ceremony.
Afterwards, when Simhahanu died,
his eldest son, Shuddhodana, naturally took his place as ruler of the kingdom.
Under the young sovereign's rule, the inhabitants of Kapilavastu lived even more happily and prosperously than they had under his father.
